instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT is the voltage rail for the backlight of the LCD screen. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_PWM: What is LCD_BKLT_PWM? LCD_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Blown fuse, Replaced fuse and Display assembly and no backlight. Suspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?
threads.message:
Hi.
Macbook came in originally with no backlight.
Confirmed display worked - with torch from behind could see login screen.
Replaced backlight, which blew again.
Tried with known good display assembly after replacing fuse - unit worked.
Returned to customer.

Now, customer returned it with the same issue.
The fan goes to maximum and stays there after a few seconds.

Replaced backlight fuse - still no backlight.
Tried with another known working display assembly - same.

Checked voltage at <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>: ONLY 12.46v
Which makes me suspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>.

Checked inputs to <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BLK</SIGNAL>: 5v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_BKL</SIGNAL>:12.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_BKL_VDDIO</SIGNAL>:3.3v
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>:2.63v (measured at pin2-<RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>).

This last one is suspicious:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL>:12.6v (measured at pin1-<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>)
BUT pin2-<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> measures 0.05v!

The resistance across <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> reads 280K ohm.
However across <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> showed only around 100 ohm, not the 100K it should.
I desoldered <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR>, and measured the two points under it and I get the same 100 ohm.
Pin2 on <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> shows 100 ohms to ground.

Given there is only 0.05v going to <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> (A3 on <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>) measured from pin2 on either <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR>, does this mean that <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> is internally shorted?

By the way, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.42v.

I do not have any spare <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>, so I removed one from another unknown faulty same logic board.
Afterwards, all the voltages are the same, and the same symptoms, although I cannot rule out that the board I took it from had the same issue.

Any suggestions on what I may have missed, or what to test next.
Any help greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Blown fuse, Replaced fuse and Display assembly and no backlight. Suspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?
threads.message:
You have had the option to check diode mode to ground when <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> removed.
Why didn't do that?
You did lot of checkings, less the most important.

No other component connected to <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>, apart of <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>.
If still low when removed, then you have a problem between traces on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Blown fuse, Replaced fuse and Display assembly and no backlight. Suspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?
threads.message:
Thanks 2informaticos.
Sorry, I'm still learning as I go.
I did checks to provide more information in my question.

Yes, that makes sense to have checked it with <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> removed...hmm, yes, I should have thought of that.
I'll take off <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>CHECKBKL_EN</SIGNAL> to ground in diode mode and report back.
Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Blown fuse, Replaced fuse and Display assembly and no backlight. Suspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?
threads.message:
With <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> removed, pad 3 (A3)(<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>) shows, in diode mode, to not be connected to ground, and is connected to pin2-<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> and pin2-<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR>.
Any other checks I should do while the chip is removed?
The only pads connected to ground are the ones that are meant to be connected to ground, i.e. A1, A2, B5, and E4.

<SIGNAL>BKL_VSYNC_R</SIGNAL> (pad D2) and <SIGNAL>BKL_FLTR</SIGNAL> (Pad C2) both look correct at 10K ohms to ground, as does <SIGNAL>BKL_FSET</SIGNAL> (Pad B4) at 16.2K Ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Blown fuse, Replaced fuse and Display assembly and no backlight. Suspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?
threads.message: Change <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and be sure to solder it correctly...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Blown fuse, Replaced fuse and Display assembly and no backlight. Suspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?
threads.message:
Thanks again 2informaticos. 
I've ordered a couple in. 
I'll update when they arrive. 
Thanks.
